image.altText: Shooting scene

items.synopsis: Police say a fatal shooting in Canterbury early this morning is believed to be a targeted incident. It comes less than 24 hours after a separate incident where a lawyer was shot.

title.children: Police probe 'common link' between recent Sydney shootings after man gunned down in city's south-west

image.altText: Kirrawee nursing home Joan Hobbs

items.synopsis: The family of Joan Hobbs have called for better staffing after the 89-year-old woman was attacked by a fellow dementia patient with a walking frame.

image.altText: Image of couple in front of cancelled and sign and Metricon label

image.altText: A composite image of Sinead O'Conner and Prince

image.altText: A Dutch player dribbles the ball as she is challenged by a USA opponent at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The USA and Netherlands finish deadlocked at 1-1 across the Tasman, as Australia prepares to cheer on the Matildas in their next group match against Nigeria this evening. Follow live.

title.children: USA, Netherlands play out tense World Cup draw, Matildas prepare for tonight's match

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a dramatic group-stage match, and it has ended in a draw. After all that, the US will be more disappointed not to get the win, as they were so dominant after getting that equaliser. They looked unstoppable once they had their full array of attacking talent going full throttle, so well done to the Dutch for holding out. Still, I think it has shown some chinks in the US armour, as they looked pretty rattled for much of that first half and some of the second. Rose Lavelle, who I maintain is the best player to watch in the world, added the dynamism the US needed in the second half. I expect she'll start for them in the next game.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FULL-TIME: USA 1 - 1 Netherlands

children.content: (Getty)
It was a dramatic group-stage match, and it has ended in a draw. After all that, the US will be more disappointed not to get the win, as they were so dominant after getting that equaliser.
They looked unstoppable once they had their full array of attacking talent going full throttle, so well done to the Dutch for holding out.
Still, I think it has shown some chinks in the US armour, as they looked pretty rattled for much of that first half and some of the second.
Rose Lavelle, who I maintain is the best player to watch in the world, added the dynamism the US needed in the second half. I expect she'll start for them in the next game.
(PressBox)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: My prediction is Australia 2 - 0 Nigeria. Goals from Raso and Gorry. You heard it here first.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Predictions time: Who's scoring the goals tonight?

children.content: My prediction is Australia 2 - 0 Nigeria.
Goals from Raso and Gorry.
You heard it here first.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just as Van de Donk seemed to rile her up, Lindsey Horan does brilliantly from the corner, angling her run to the near post and heading home with power. It's 1-1! Really great header when you see it on replay, diverted with venom into the top corner.

children.content: Just as Van de Donk seemed to rile her up, Lindsey Horan does brilliantly from the corner, angling her run to the near post and heading home with power.
Really great header when you see it on replay, diverted with venom into the top corner.
(Getty)

image.altText: A holding pen crammed with goats on a clear, sunny day.

image.altText: A woman in a brown apron stands frowning behind a counter in a cafe with a coffee machine.

image.altText: Laughing woman, long black hair, eyes shut, head thrown back, seated at kitchen table with laughing grey-haired ma, white shirt.

image.altText: The view over nepal from a paraglider.

image.altText: John Woodman sits in a chair in front of a microphone against a wooden wall as he testifies at the IBAC hearing in Melbourne.

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

items.synopsis: The ASX has set a 100-day high as the market continues to digest yesterday's better than expected inflation numbers, while in the US, stocks finished flat as the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates to a 22-year high. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Fed 'prepared to raise further' as rates hit 22-year high, ASX up in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The EY review was commissioned in September 2022 following the death of auditor Aishwarya Venkat in the firm's Sydney office. More than 4,500 current and former employees were surveyed across Australia and New Zealand. EY says it has already put in place measures to support well being and workplace culture including mental health first aid staff and welfare contact officers. The report found that many of the problems identified are known challenges across professional services firms in Australia, particularly overwork. EY Oceania chief executive David Larocca says the firm has fallen short of the standard that everyone who works at EY has a right to expect. “There are findings in the report that are distressing and completely unacceptable. Bullying, sexual harassment and racism have no place at EY Oceania and I apologise to anyone who has suffered as a result.” " The impact of long working hours is also significant and taking a heavy toll on the well being of many of our people.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EY boss says report findings are 'distressing and completely unacceptable'

children.content: The EY review was commissioned in September 2022 following the death of auditor Aishwarya Venkat in the firm's Sydney office.
More than 4,500 current and former employees were surveyed across Australia and New Zealand.
EY says it has already put in place measures to support well being and workplace culture including mental health first aid staff and welfare contact officers.
The report found that many of the problems identified are known challenges across professional services firms in Australia, particularly overwork.
EY Oceania chief executive David Larocca says the firm has fallen short of the standard that everyone who works at EY has a right to expect.

“There are findings in the report that are distressing and completely unacceptable. Bullying, sexual harassment and racism have no place at EY Oceania and I apologise to anyone who has suffered as a result.”
" The impact of long working hours is also significant and taking a heavy toll on the well being of many of our people.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Staff at big consulting firm EY Oceania say they have experienced bullying, sexual harassment, racism, and overwork. These are the findings of a major report by former sex discrimination commissioner Elizabeth Broderick, which was commissioned by EY after an auditor killed herself at the company's office in Sydney. It comes amid intense scrutiny of the big four consultancy firms amid the PwC tax leaks scandal. Major findings: 15 per cent of staff have experienced bullying 10 per cent experienced sexual harassment 8 per cent experienced racism 46 per cent say their health has been negatively affected by overwork 31 per cent are working 51 or more hours a week 11 per cent are working 61 or more hours a week 94 per cent said they felt safe in the workplace 74 per cent said they rarely feel excluded in the workplace, suggesting a significant minority at times do feel excluded.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EY staff feel bullied, harassed and overworked

children.content: Staff at big consulting firm EY Oceania say they have experienced bullying, sexual harassment, racism, and overwork.
These are the findings of a major report by former sex discrimination commissioner Elizabeth Broderick, which was commissioned by EY after an auditor killed herself at the company's office in Sydney.
It comes amid intense scrutiny of the big four consultancy firms amid the PwC tax leaks scandal.
Major findings:
15 per cent of staff have experienced bullying
10 per cent experienced sexual harassment
8 per cent experienced racism
46 per cent say their health has been negatively affected by overwork
31 per cent are working 51 or more hours a week
11 per cent are working 61 or more
hours a week
94 per cent said they felt safe in the workplace
74 per cent said they rarely feel excluded in the workplace, suggesting a significant minority at times do feel excluded.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Planners, builders and insurers are calling on state governments to overhaul planning rules to prevent homes being built on flood plains. The Insurance Council of Australia, Master Builders Australia, and the Planning Institute of Australia, supported by the Australian Local Government Association, want planning rules changed so no more homes are built in high-risk flood prone locations. They held an industry round table to day to press their case. Planning ministers will report this year on developing a national standard for considering disaster and climate risk, and end development on flood plains. Here's Andrew Hall, chief executive of the Insurance Council of Australia: "The flood events of 2022, with almost 300,000 disaster-related claims costing around $7 billion, has driven up premiums and has resulted in affordability constraints for those at highest risk." Matt Collins, chief executive of the Planning Institute of Australia, says new risk-based policies are needed to avoid or minimise exposure to floods. "Planning is a critical tool for influencing the level of future disaster risk, and our changing climate means we need to act now to limit the impact of extreme weather on our communities." Councillor Linda Scott, president of the Australian Local Government Association: "Australia’s 537 councils play a vital role in building resilient communities, assisting in every corner of the nation to ensure our communities can better prepare for, respond to and recover from increasing natural disasters." "It’s crucial we rebuild damaged local infrastructure to a more resilient standard."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Call to stop building homes in flood prone areas

children.content: Planners, builders and insurers are calling on state governments to overhaul planning rules to prevent homes being built on flood plains.

The Insurance Council of Australia, Master Builders Australia, and the Planning Institute of Australia, supported by the Australian Local Government Association, want planning rules changed so no more homes are built in high-risk flood prone locations.
They held an industry round table to day to press their case.
Planning ministers will report this year on developing a national standard for considering disaster and climate risk, and end development on flood plains.
Here's Andrew Hall, chief executive of the Insurance Council of Australia:
"The flood events of 2022, with almost 300,000 disaster-related claims costing around $7 billion, has driven up premiums and has resulted in affordability constraints for those at highest risk."
Matt Collins, chief executive of the Planning Institute of Australia,
says new risk-based policies are needed to avoid or minimise exposure to floods.
"Planning is a critical tool for influencing the level of future disaster risk, and our changing climate means we need to act now to limit the impact of extreme weather on our communities."
Councillor Linda Scott, president of the Australian Local Government Association:

"Australia’s 537 councils play a vital role in building resilient communities, assisting in every corner of the nation to ensure our communities can better prepare for, respond to and recover from increasing natural disasters."
"It’s crucial we rebuild damaged local infrastructure to a more resilient standard."
